key_insight: A network-aware, self-supervised representation learning method captures rich neuronal activity dynamics from high-content recordings, enabling systematic phenotypic screening to identify genetic modifiers of neural activity across diverse interventions.
problem_solved: Conventional screening struggles to extract reliable, generalizable phenotypes from large, noisy neuronal activity datasets and to link those phenotypes to genetic perturbations across varying experimental conditions.
method: Integrate network-aware inductive biases (spatial/functional connectivity) into a self-supervised learning objective to learn robust activity representations without labels.
Encode temporal activity traces and local network context, then use learned embeddings to cluster and compare phenotypes across genetic perturbations and interventions.
Perform high-content screening by scoring and ranking candidate genetic modifiers based on embedding shifts and phenotype separability across conditions.
impact: Provides a scalable, label-free pipeline for AI-driven phenotypic discovery in neuroscience, lowering the barrier to identify genetic modulators of activity and accelerating hypothesis generation for experimental follow-up.
visual_elements: Schematic of model: temporal encoder + network-aware module feeding into a self-supervised loss
Example neuronal activity traces with corresponding learned embeddings (before vs after perturbation)
Dimensionality reduction map (e.g., UMAP) showing clusters of phenotypes and highlighted genetic hits
Bar/heatmap comparing hit rates or effect sizes across different interventions/genetic perturbations
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
